Name: Rumtek Monastery
Description: The largest monastery in Sikkim, it is the seat of the Karmapa Lama.
OverviewText: Known as the Dharmachakra Centre, Rumtek is a stunning example of Tibetan Buddhist architecture. It houses some of the world's most unique religious scriptures and art objects.

Name: Pemayangtse Monastery
Description: One of the oldest and most important monasteries in Sikkim, known for its intricate wooden sculptures.
OverviewText: Founded in 1705, Pemayangtse translates to 'Perfect Sublime Lotus'. It is affiliated with the Nyingma school of Tibetan Buddhism and offers breathtaking views of Mount Khangchendzonga.

Name: Tashiding Monastery
Description: Considered one of the holiest monasteries in Sikkim, located on a heart-shaped hill.
OverviewText: It is believed that a single glimpse of this monastery can cleanse all sins. The monastery is famous for the Bhumchu festival, a sacred water ceremony that draws devotees from all over.

Name: Enchey Monastery
Description: An important seat of the Nyingma order, this 200-year-old monastery is located in the capital city, Gangtok.
OverviewText: The name 'Enchey' means 'the solitary temple'. The monastery is believed to be blessed by the protective deity, Khangchendzonga, making it a significant place of worship.

Name: Ralang Monastery
Description: Known for its impressive collection of paintings and thangkas, it is one of the most significant monasteries of the Kagyu school.
OverviewText: Rebuilt in 1995, the new Ralang Monastery is a magnificent structure. It hosts the Pang Lhabsol festival and the traditional Mahakala dance, attracting numerous tourists and pilgrims.

Name: Dubdi Monastery
Description: Also known as the Yuksom Monastery, it is considered the oldest monastery in Sikkim, established in 1701.
OverviewText: Dubdi translates to 'the retreat'. This serene monastery is a significant historical site as it's connected to the coronation of the first Chogyal (king) of Sikkim.

Name: Sangachoeling Monastery
Description: Established in the 17th century by Lama Lhatsun Chempo, it is one of the oldest monasteries in the state.
OverviewText: The name means 'island of the secret spell'. Located on a high ridge opposite Pemayangtse, it offers stunning views and houses ancient statues, paintings, and scriptures.

Name: Phensang Monastery
Description: Home to around 300 monks of the Nyingmapa order, it is one of the largest monasteries in Sikkim.
OverviewText: The monastery was established in 1721 by Lama Jigme Pawo. Although damaged by a fire in 1947, it was rebuilt quickly and stands today as a testament to the faith of its followers.

Name: Phodong Monastery
Description: A major monastery of the Kagyu school of Tibetan Buddhism, it houses beautiful murals and ancient religious artifacts.
OverviewText: The monastery was founded by the 4th Chogyal Gyurmed Namgyal. It has a similar architectural design to the Rumtek Monastery and is a significant center for Buddhist learning.

Name: Lingdum Monastery (Ranka)
Description: Also known as Ranka Monastery, it is a relatively new but vast and spectacular complex spread over a large area.
OverviewText: Following the traditional Tibetan architectural style, Lingdum is a major tourist attraction. It maintains a monastic school and serves as a peaceful retreat for monks and visitors.

Name: Tsuklakhang Palace
Description: This was the royal monastery for the Chogyal dynasty and was the main center for coronations and royal marriages.
OverviewText: Located within the palace grounds in Gangtok, it houses an extensive collection of Buddhist scriptures. The monastery is a beautiful example of traditional Sikkimese architecture.

Name: Kartok Monastery
Description: One of the three major monasteries of the Nyingma school in Sikkim, located in the historic town of Yuksom.
OverviewText: This serene monastery, with the holy Kartok lake in front, is an important pilgrimage site. It is named after a lama who was one of the three who consecrated the first king of Sikkim.
